snippet: Assistance is expected to accelerate as tens of thousands of people left homeless by Hurricane Sandy look for places to stay.
abstract: New York State officials are working to provide temporary housing for people displaced by Hurricane Sandy, despite confusion and conflicting accounts of how many people need places to live; federal officials say more than 45,000 families in New York have been approved for housing assistance that would let them find a temporary place to live while repairs to damaged homes and apartment buildings are made.

byline.original: By JAMES BARRON, ERIC LIPTON and RAY RIVERA

lead_paragraph: Assistance is expected to accelerate as tens of thousands of people left homeless by Hurricane Sandy look for places to stay.

headline.seo: Housing Relocation Begins After Hurricane Sandy With Federal Aid
headline.main: With $200 Million in U.S. Housing Aid, Officials Begin Relocating the Displaced
headline.print_headline: With $200 Million in U.S. Housing Aid, Officials Begin Relocating the Displaced
